comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called ANYTHING GOES SCOTLAND,VINTAGE PHOTOS,POSTCARDS,EPHEMERAetc..., and we'd love to have this added to the group!

comment.author: 42875509@N00
comment._content:
Nice, these old images are fantastic.

Not sure how the names have changed over the years, but to me this shows Union Street in the centre, and King Street to the right. The area in the foreground is known as Castlegate I think.

comment.author: 63404131@N00
comment._content: hasn't changed much at all, there are no railings round the merkat cross now -- Seen in some comments. (?)

comment.author: 24049533@N00
comment._content: View now, from the cross in the picture above.

comment.author: 34763856@N06
comment._content: very beautiful places....but why taken in 1890

comment.author: 31566446@N05
comment._content:
Both King Street and Union street were called as such at this time. 

behind the merkat cross you can just see a small showing of flowers there is another image somewhere that shows this had 2 sets of steps down to a lower level, there is no sign of this now, and hasn't been for many years. (I have no idea what it was for! public toilets maybe?!)

The statue which you can see beside a hut or something in the middle was moved to beside HMT / Union Terrace Gardens, near to William Wallace statue.

comment.author: 48809099@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/lola_black] Hi Lola. Yes their were public toilets below street level and this was one of the reasons the area was a major bus terminus. The Statue looks to be Gordon of Khartoum and as you correctly say it sits in a tiny park in front of the Robert Gordon's College on Schoolhill. If you look at the arch at the right shoulder of the statue its the entrance to Lodge Walk the old Police Headquarters. The old jail "The Tolbooth", is sited inside the arch and on Union Street there is a small brass plaque where the gallows was sited for executions. Opposite King Street is Marshall Street and my Great Great grandfather was marched to a ship from the jail with a ball and chain and sent to Australia for stealing a horse.
